section.name: Joda Time - Java date and time API
section.p: Joda-Time aims to provide a quality replacement for the Java date and time classes. The design allows for multiple calendar systems, while still providing simple API. The 'default' calendar is the ISO8601 standard which is used by XML. The Gregorian, Julian, Buddhist and Coptic systems are also included, and we welcome further additions. Supporting classes include time zone, duration, format and parsing.

The decision to create a cleanroom date implementation to replace Java's is based on the flaws in the JDK code. Date should have been immutable, like String, instead it is mutable and has many deprecated methods. Calendar makes accessing 'normal' dates difficult, due to the lack of simple methods. It also has some strange performance characteristics as it recalculates fields at unexpected moments.

section.name: Releases
section.p: Release 0.95 is the current latest release. This release is stable in that it tells the right time, and we are aware of sites where it has been used in production. However, there have been significant API changes to the CVS version since 0.95, all resulting from issues identified in testing. It is hoped to release a new release in Q4 2004.

section.name: Support
section.p: For support on bugs, using the library or to volunteer please contact the mailing list (or email direct to the list via joda-interest@lists.sourceforge.net).
Alternatively, you can contact the project lead, Stephen Colebourne via scolebourne@users.sourceforge.net.
